Award.AwardTitle: Rheo-Control 3D Printing: Tuning Suspension Viscosity for Fabricating Functional Materials with Gradient Properties

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant supports research that will contribute new knowledge related to an additive manufacturing process, promoting both the progress of science and advancing national prosperity. Additive manufacturing, often called 3D printing, plays a pivotal role in the rapid design and fabrication of technological devices without the need for expensive tooling and long turnaround times. However, high-performance 3D printing of functional devices, such as energy-absorbing materials, wearable electronics, and morphing structures, remains a major challenge. Such limitations in performance are largely attributed to the difficulty in extruding highly functional inks and actively controlling their properties. This award supports fundamental research to provide knowledge for developing a 3D printing process that extrudes high-performance inks with tunable properties. The new printing technology will improve the performance of current 3D-printed devices and unlock new designs in material fabrication, bio-manufacturing, and customizable electronic production. Therefore, results from this research will greatly benefit the U.S. economy and society. This research involves multiple disciplines including fluid mechanics, microfabrication, and materials science. This transdisciplinary approach will help broaden participation of underrepresented groups in research and promote equity and inclusion in engineering education.

Functional inks in 3D printing are often extremely viscous due to the required high filler content, and they often exhibit shear jamming that leads to catastrophic nozzle clogging. Moreover, the inability to alter ink properties, such as rigidity, conductivity, and thermal response, constrains manufacturing and thus inhibits the potential of realizing many new designs. To address such a challenge, this research will develop an understanding of and strategies for controlling functional ink properties via ultrasonic acoustic fields during extrusion. The hypothesis builds upon recent advances in thickening suspensions, in which high-frequency perturbations can be used to manipulate the microstructure of viscous fluids and substantially reduce their flow resistance. Specifically, this project will investigate the relationship between the mechanical properties of a particle-based model ink and the inkâ€™s acoustically altered microstructure. The integration of these findings will lead to the development of design principles and perturbation protocols for building printing platforms. The project will explore two perturbation approaches: first, the simple attachment of a piezoelectric to a printing nozzle, and second, the engineering of an acoustic patterning device that precisely controls the ink microstructure. Collectively, these experiments will provide a foundation for developing active control of ink properties for printing functional devices.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Performance_Institution.Name: The Regents of the University of California, Los Angeles

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The outcomes of this project significantly advanced the fields of additive manufacturing, rheology, and the understanding of living materials with heterogeneous mechanical properties, while making a broader impact on education, technology, and society. The project focused on overcoming key challenges in 3D printing, particularly in the use of functional inks, by developing innovative techniques to control their properties dynamically. Using ultrasonic acoustic fields, researchers demonstrated the ability to modulate ink viscosity and particle alignment during the printing process, paving the way for the fabrication of high-performance materials such as bio-inspired structures, energy-absorbing devices, and custom scaffolds for biomedical applications.
A central innovation of the project was the development of a novel 3D printing platform equipped with piezoelectric acoustic actuators. This technology enabled real-time control over material properties during extrusion, improving the precision, efficiency, and versatility of 3D printing processes. These advancements contribute to intellectual merit by addressing fundamental questions about the interplay between acoustic forces and material behavior, expanding theoretical and practical knowledge in additive manufacturing.
In the study of living materials with heterogeneous mechanical properties, the project introduced new experimental tools, such as a membrane stretcher combined with AI-enhanced microscopy, to analyze strain distribution and mechanical behaviors in cellular systems. The findings revealed how acoustic fields and mechanical forces influence strain heterogeneity and mechanical responses in living cellular systems, providing insights into the relationship between mechanical heterogeneity and function in complex biological materials. These discoveries contribute to our understanding of how living systems respond to external forces, which is critical for applications in tissue engineering and biomaterial science.
Beyond its scientific contributions, the project achieved significant broader impacts by fostering interdisciplinary education and training. Graduate and undergraduate students gained valuable experience in experimental design, computational modeling, and advanced imaging techniques, equipping them with critical skills for careers in science, engineering, and technology. The project also shared its innovations openly, releasing hardware designs and AI tools to promote accessibility and collaboration across academic, industrial, and public sectors.
The societal impacts of this work include potential applications in healthcare, such as customizable medical devices, and sustainable manufacturing practices that reduce waste and environmental impact. The emphasis on open-source technologies and interdisciplinary training promotes equity and inclusivity, enabling diverse groups to engage with and benefit from cutting-edge research.
Overall, this project advanced the frontiers of additive manufacturing and related disciplines, while contributing to the understanding of the mechanical heterogeneity of living materials. It made meaningful contributions to education, technology transfer, and societal well-being, demonstrating both intellectual merit and broad societal impact.


Last Modified: 12/03/2024
Modified by: Neil Y Lin

In the study of living materials with heterogeneous mechanical properties, the project introduced new experimental tools, such as a membrane stretcher combined with AI-enhanced microscopy, to analyze strain distribution and mechanical behaviors in cellular systems.
